questions.question_text: Following a recent data breach, a company has hired a new Chief Information Security Officer (CISO). The CISO is very concerned about the response time to the previous breach and wishes to know how the security team expects to react to a future attack. Which of the following is the BEST method to achieve this goal while minimizing disruption?

discussion.content: C. A tabletop exercise is an. activity in which key personnel assigned emergency management roles and responsibilities are gathered to discuss, in a non-threatening environment, various simulated emergency situations. So you can know as CISO how are they going to react and minimum disruption.

Maybe: B. Hire an external red team audit ?
If the employees knew when the audit would take place, it would not disrupt operations. 
And external team could be more knowledgeable, and more objective, than an in-house team. An outside team probably does this all the time. There is no indication that the in-house staff has ever done this.

questions.question_text:
A Chief Security Officer (CSO) is reviewing the organization's incident response report from a recent incident. The details of the event indicate:
1. A user received a phishing email that appeared to be a report from the organization's CRM tool.
2. The user attempted to access the CRM tool via a fraudulent web page but was unable to access the tool.
3. The user, unaware of the compromised account, did not report the incident and continued to use the CRM tool with the original credentials.
4. Several weeks later, the user reported anomalous activity within the CRM tool.
5. Following an investigation, it was determined the account was compromised and an attacker in another country has gained access to the CRM tool.
6. Following identification of corrupted data and successful recovery from the incident, a lessons learned activity was to be led by the CSO.
Which of the following would MOST likely have allowed the user to more quickly identify the unauthorized use of credentials by the attacker?

discussion.content:
Maybe: F. WAYF-based authentication?
This is a tool specifically designed to do exactly what the question is asking for:
 Where Are You From (WAYF) service:
 - guides a user to his or her Identity Provider (IdP)
 - also known as: "Identity Provider Discovery" service
 - present the user a list of Identity Providers (IdPs) and redirect the user's web browser to the selected Identity Provider (IdP) or back to the Service Provider (the web application that the user is trying to access)
- also known as: "Identity Provider Discovery" service

comments.content: On second thought, I think I may have misunderstood what a WAYF does. I think I will stick with "security training"

discussion.content: CRM tool does not support Last Login verification on client side only admin side for audit purposes. It means the user will never know last login info unless he ask directly to the CRM admin. I think A is the answer.

B.
A is not a security control to identify compromised accounts, it's a preventative measure to stop the account from being compromised in the first place.

B.
"Security awareness training" will not let the user identify the unauthorized use of his account.

comments.content: Unless they're trained to look then B doesn't amount to squat. Their answer is correct.

The user should have been able to recognize, and report, the suspicious occurrences.

"The user attempted to access the CRM tool via a fraudulent web page but was unable to access the tool.,, The user, unaware of the compromised account, did not report the incident..."

A better trained user might have known enough to see this a suspicious, and report the incident. Or, a better trained user may have known to get to the CRM by opening a tab, and entering the URL, instead of clicking a link. Or, a better trained user may have known to, at least, look at the URL before attempting to logon.
You pretty much overthink "most" of the questions asked. I have read some of your answers and you have the same approach "overthinking". even when it is straightforward.

Maybe: B. Perform a code review of the attachment ? 
It is not likely that any code is available. But, maybe the analyst could de-compile, or search the binary for strings? At least, this might "determine whether or not the attachment is safe."
Horrible question. Completely unfair.

discussion.content:
All of the answers are wrong. The question is unfair. 
The security analyst needs to determine if the attachment is safe. Placing the attachment in a malware sandbox, of itself, will not determine anything. 
Performing a code review of the attachment might determine something. But it is unlikely that the code is available.

questions.question_text: An organization's Chief Financial Officer (CFO) was the target of several different social engineering attacks recently. The CFO has subsequently worked closely with the Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) to increase awareness of what attacks may look like. An unexpected email arrives in the CFO's inbox from a familiar name with an attachment. Which of the following should the CISO task a security analyst with to determine whether or not the attachment is safe?

choices.C: Conduct a memory dump of the CFO's PC.
choices.B: Perform a code review of the attachment.
choices.D: Run a vulnerability scan on the email server.
choices.A: Place it in a malware sandbox.

choices.C: Network engineers are not following SOPs.
choices.B: Network engineers have ignored defacto standards.
choices.A: There are open standards in use on the network.
choices.D: The network has competing standards in use.

discussion.content:
Maybe: C. Network engineers are not following SOPs ?
According to the question: "The CISO has not discovered any governance documentation." 
I suppose that means: there are no SOPs to follow. I could see that as a problem.

comments.content: If there is no governance, then there won't be an agreed SOPs to follow. It would all be subjective. The counterargument by engineers would be 'we haven't done anything wrong'.

Exactly. And that is the problem. There needs to be some governance documentation, such as SOPs. Network engineers are not following SOPs, because there are no SOPs to follow. 
BTW: what do you think is the answer?

discussion.content: From a *security* standpoint: what is wrong with competing standards?

comments.content:
Again: "The CISO has not discovered any governance documentation." 
1. No need for different cabling standards to tell you there is no governance and oversight. It is spelled out in the question.
2. Two slightly different cabling standards might not violate any governance anyway.
3. Since the questions asks about the CISO's concern, it would certainly relate to security concerns.
There is no security implication per se. This question is aiming at governance and oversight. having 2 different cabling standards means that there is none.
